titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the Chang Kia-ngau papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Hoover Institution Archives Staff, revised by Yichen Jin

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-06-08T13:45-0700

change.item: Added Box 32 to reflect preservation housing changes. Box 32 consists of items that were formerly in Box 29 (Rita Wang).
Revised to correct folder titles and dates (David Sun).
Added new container list and revised front matter.
Revised to update encoding and add unitid.
PUBLIC "-//Stanford University::Hoover Institution Archives//TEXT (US::CSt-H::::Kia-ngau Chang Papers)//EN" "chang.sgm" converted from EAD 1.0 to 2002 by v1to02.cdl.xsl (2004-09-16).

did.unittitle: Chang Kia-ngau papers

physdesc.extent: 26 manuscript boxes, 5 oversize boxes, 1 card file box, 1 envelope, 4 panels of calligraphy

did.abstract: Diaries, letters, writings, reports, financial records, instructions, statistics, and printed matter relating to financial and economic conditions in China, economic conditions in Manchuria at the end of World War II, Chinese-Soviet negotiations for the return of Manchuria to Chinese control, and daily commodity prices of Chinese products, 1950-1957. Includes some materials collected from Japanese organizations, calligraphy by Liang Qichao, and letters by Chiang Kai-shek. Part of collection also available on microfilm (11 reels).

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Chang Kia-ngau papers, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Last Chance in Manchuria: The Diary of Chang Kia-ngau, edited by Donald G. Gillin and Ramon H. Myers, translated by Dolores Zen. Hoover Institution Press, 1989.

chronitem.event: Editor-in-chief of the Official Gazette published by the Ministry of Communications
Began his banking career as assistant manager of the Bank of China in Shanghai
Contributed to the development of modern practices in private banking in China, fending off government control of the Bank of China
During the Sino-Japanese war, served as Minister of Communications, accompanying the central government from Nanking to Chungking

eventgrp.event: Held various other positions of importance in the Chinese Nationalist Government

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Diaries, letters, writings, reports, financial records, instructions, statistics, and printed matter relating to financial and economic conditions in China, economic conditions in Manchuria at the end of World War II, Chinese-Soviet negotiations for the return of Manchuria to Chinese control, and daily commodity prices of Chinese products, 1950-1957. Includes some materials collected from Japanese organizations, calligraphy by Liang Qichao, and letters by Chiang Kai-shek. Part of collection also available on microfilm (11 reels).

did.unittitle: Diaries,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes diaries documenting the Japanese invasion of Manchuria.

did.unittitle: Ping Shou Chai diary,
Dong Bei Jie Shou Jiao She Ri Ji (Diary of Taking Over Northeastern China),
Diaries and small memorandums,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One diary is from 1940; unclear if actually used in that year. There is also a photo inside it of an unidentified woman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains envelope for Chang Chinn-mau letter regarding conditions after World War II, and the decisions of Chiang Kai-shek, but letter itself is not included.
